metadata.case_name: Holder of Taluk Kakwara v. Banaili Raj

facts.text: Appellant is present holder of Taluk Kakwara appertaining to Mahalat Kharakpur. Respondents represent Banaili Raj which acquired Mahalat of Kharakpur.
Respondents obtained decree for Rs. 11,587-14-6 against appellant for arrears of rent and cess and applied for execution by attachment and sale of Taluk Kakwara.
On August 29, 1939, appellant filed objection under section 47 CPC alleging Taluk Kakwara held on Ghatwali tenure could not be sold in execution of money decree.
Objection overruled by Subordinate Judge of Bhagalpur in Mis. Case No. 174 of 1939 on 13th July, 1940, holding it Zamindari Ghatwali under Raja of Kharakpur.
On May 31, 1940, appellant filed fresh objection under section 47 CPC claiming Taluk Kakwara held under Government Ghatwali tenure.

High Court of Patna appeal No. 238 of 1940: Manohar Lal J. held Government Ghatwali; Shearer J. held became Zamindari Ghatwali; referred to Chatterjee J. who held Zamindari Ghatwali and dismissed appeal on 22nd November, 1944.
Appeal to Privy Council, transferred to Supreme Court.
Ghatwali tenures originated in Moghul period for police and military services guarding mountain passes.
In Kharakpur, Ghatwali tenures alienable with assent of Zamindar per custom in Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy (1887).
1765: East India Company secured Dewani. Mozaffar Ali Raja of Kharakpur rebelled in 1766, subdued 1768, estate managed by Company till restored to Kadir Ali in 1780.
1776/1777: Captain Browne granted Sanad (Exhibit 1) to Rankoo Singh and Bhairo Singh, ghatwals of Taluk Kakwara, 22 villages, fixed jama Rs. 245-12-15, duties including protection of tenants.
1780: Raja Kadir Ali Sanad (Exhibit 1a) to same grantees, Ghatwali service tenure, 16 mauzas, 172 musketeers/archers, fixed quit-rent Rs. 245-12-15 inclusive of Zamindari rasoom.
1789/1790 decennial settlement, 1796 permanent under Regulation I of 1793; Taluk Kakwara included in Zamindari assessment.
Lists in 1860 and 1863 by Government show Kakwara as one of 98 Ghatwali Mahals appertaining to Kharakpur.
Handwa, Lachmipur, Chandan Katoria treated as Government Ghatwalis, not in Kharakpur lists.

legal_issues.text: Whether Taluk Kakwara is a Government Ghatwali tenure (inalienable) or Zamindari Ghatwali tenure under Kharakpur Zamindar (alienable with assent).

petitioner_arguments.text: Taluk Kakwara is Government Ghatwali tenure, inalienable, cannot be sold in execution.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Custom for Government Ghatwalis; Captain Browne Sanad created Government tenure; Kadir Ali Sanad confirmatory.

petitioner_arguments.text: Captain Browne Sanad addressed to Zamindars etc., fixed jama to Government treasury, during interregnum indicates Government grant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Narayan Singh v. Niranjan Chakravarti; Rani Songbari Kumari v. Raja Kirtyanand Singh

respondent_arguments.text: Taluk Kakwara is Zamindari Ghatwali under Kharakpur Raja, alienable with assent; sale in execution for rent arrears implies assent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy; custom in Kharakpur.

respondent_arguments.text: Sanads confirm Zamindari tenure; included in Permanent Settlement; Government lists as Kharakpur Ghatwali.

court_reasoning.text: Ghatwali tenures vary: Government direct inalienable; Kharakpur Zamindari alienable with assent per custom.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Custom judicially recognised in Kali Pershad.

court_reasoning.text: Captain Browne Sanad (1777) likely confirmation of existing Zamindari tenure during interregnum; duties ordinary Zamindar duties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No stipulation for definite armed force.

court_reasoning.text: Kadir Ali Sanad (1780) regularises as Zamindari Ghatwali: different mauzas, apportionment, inclusive rasoom, 98 such sanads vs 3 Government.
Permanent Settlement included in Zamindari; Government lists confirm; distinguished from Handwa.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if originally Government, became Zamindari post-sanads/settlement.

holdings.text: Taluk Kakwara is Zamindari Ghatwali tenure, alienable with assent of Zamindar.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Kharakpur Ghatwalis alienable with Zamindar assent.
Distinguishes Government vs Zamindari Ghatwalis; Handwa independent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Lelanund Singh v. Government Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Kharakpur Ghatwalis part of Zamindari; Zamindar appoints/dismisses.

precedents_cited.case_name: Leelanund Singh v. Thakoor Munranjan Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Taluk Kakwara dependent taluk of Kharakpur Zamindari.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rani Songbari Kumari v. Raja Kirtyanand Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Handwa Government Ghatwali; differences from Kakwara.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Regulation I of 1793
statutes_cited.relevance: Permanent Settlement; Ghatwali lands included in Zamindari assessment, not resumable.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court and lower court orders overruling objection to execution sale of Taluk Kakwara, holding it Zamindari Ghatwali alienable with Zamindar assent.

key_quotes.text: "Ghatwali tenures held under the Zamindar of Kharakpur were, by custom judicially recognised, alienable with the assent of the Zamindar"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the true view to take was that such a tenure in Kharakpur was not inalienable, and might be transferred by the Ghatwal or sold in execution of a decree against him, if such transfer or sale was assented to by the Zamindar."
key_quotes.speaker: court
